Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Southern Hemisphere Processes and Global Climate Change: The Evolution of Late Miocene to Present Surface Ocean Conditions in the Southern Hemisphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers from Lafayette and Luther Colleges, together with their undergraduate students, will investigate southern hemisphere climate change over the last six million years in order to better understand key linkages and feedbacks within the Earth's climate system. This research focuses on a region of the world -- the southern hemisphere -- whose climate history has been largely unexplored previously, but that is known to play a critical role in important climate and oceanic processes related to carbon cycling, deep ocean ventilation, and tropical heat exchange dynamics. Additionally, this project will include a detailed investigation of climate dynamics during an interval in Earth's history when global temperatures were a few degrees warmer than today's and the size of the Greenland ice sheet was much reduced. Thus, this study will provide a clearer understanding of climate conditions during an interval that represents a potential analog for future climate conditions given current patterns of anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions. Specifically, the researchers will examine the symmetry of climate evolution between the northern and southern hemispheres and the evolving response of the climate system to changes in climate forcing due to cyclic changes in the position and orientation of the Earth in its orbit relative to the Sun.

Beyond the scientific questions addressed in this research, this project will also advance the early preparation of future Earth scientists who will have the skills to face both the scientific and societal challenges presented by climate change. Undergraduate student researchers involved with this project will gain hands-on experience in the nature and process of scientific research, direct training in the field of paleoclimatology, critical thinking skills related to scientific research and a deeper introduction to the systems thinking skills that distinguish the Earth scientist's approach to understanding the world. In addition, outreach to local K-12 students and educators by the principle investigators and their research students will further disseminate the results of this work as well as the broader contributions of paleoclimatic research and climate science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The changes in our climate system underway today underscore the necessity of understanding climate system behavior. Human records of climate conditions extend back in time just a few centuries at best, capturing only a limited range of natural climate system variability and furhermore, documenting conditions which are unlikely to be similar to our future, in which atmospheric CO2 levels will be higher than they have been for the last three million years or more. For this reason, paleoclimatologists investigate the climate of Earth's deeper past in order to better understand the ranges of climate conditions the Earth has experienced and the specific climate system processes that have operated in the past and which may operate again in our future climate as well.

In our study, we analyzed chemical changes in layers of seafloor sediments to construct a record of sea surface temperature change in the southwest Pacific Ocean for the past 3.8 million years. Our record is one of the first long climate records from the southern hemisphere, and the high resolution of our record (one data point every 2000-3000 years) allows us to examine past climate behavior in this region in great detail and to compare southern hemisphere climate evolution with existing records from the northern hemisphere and tropics.

We found that long term cooling from 3.8 million years ago to the present was roughly symmetric across the hemispheres, and also that the temperature gradient from the equator to the mid-latitudes grew in tandem with the east-west temperature gradient across the equatorial Pacific, which evolved from permanent El Nino-like conditions during the Pliocene to temperature conditions like those of today, which are marked by a strong contrast between warmer waters in the west and cooler waters in the east. Our findings suggest that the conditions of the eastern equatorial Pacific are very sensitive to changes in mid-latitude climate, which are important to understand because conditions in the eastern equatorial Pacific strongly impact climate in other regions.

Although we found that the pattern of long term southern hemisphere cooling from the Pliocene to the present was symmetric with cooling in the northern hemipshere, we also observed an important divergence in southern hemisphere climate behavior. Whereas northern hemisphere and tropical climate records fluctuated in regular 41-thousand year glacial-interglacial cycles during the late Pliocene and early Pleistocene and were strongly coordinated with each other, we found that southern hemisphere temperature records do not show a strong 41-thousand year beat and coordination to other climate records until approximately 1.6 million years ago. Strong 41-thousand year cycles emerge in the southern hemisphere at the same time that the cycles became amplified in northern hemisphere and tropical climate records. This finding supports recent hypotheses that enhanced iron fertilization and carbon sequestration in the Southern Ocean beginning ~1.6 million years ago amplified the greenhouse gas feedbacks associated with glacial-interglacial cycles, and provides important insight into the relationship between background climate conditions and the climate system feedbacks at play.

In addition to our scientific findings, this project has also introduced undergraduate students to research in paleoclimatology and fostered the development of their skills in scientific research and communication. This project has also helped educate undergraduate students about the science of climate change and complex Earth system behavior, thus helping both to train future scientists in a critical field and to increase public literacy on climate and Earth system change.
